reviews.review_text: To start off, I can't say that this is my favorite NFS game of all time, but it is certainly up there. I have been a NFS fan for a long time, dating back to the good old PS2 days with Most Wanted and Carbon. So far no other NFS game, in my opinion, has been better than those, but Hot Pursuit is still a lot of fun, and here's why.   PROS:   The graphics are fantastic. The car models are awesome as always, and the scenery is beautiful. Yes, scenery especially matters to me because I want to be able to go for a nice drive, if that's what I'm in the mood for. It looks great at 200+ MPH too! Now don't expect Metro: Last Light graphics, but it really is a nice looking game.  There are quite a few cars as well. I can't say for sure how many there are, but it's certainly enough to keep you busy with trying certain races with different cars or just taking them for a spin. Not to mention that for every normal car in the game there is a cop car counterpart, with the addition of a couple! So if driving at 250 MPH on a freeway with sirens on sounds fun to you, please give this a try! But what about how they handle?  I personally enjoy how the cars handle in this. It is NOT a simulator in any way. It is arcade style racing with easy drifting so you can boost into those corners like a boss without losing tons of speed or control. To me it seems like all the cars handle in a very similar fashion, but I actually don't mind it. I don't think this type of racing is for everyone however, but it's not hard at all to get used to. Remember that this game is all about going fast to evade cops or bust racers using special abilities, so you can't be completely focused on realistic driving. But that brings me to another thing I love about this.  In the game, whether you are a racer or a cop, you have access to EMPs, spike strips, roadblocks, extreme turbo, and more. All these make the game more exciting and tense. If you are a racer, you can drop spike strips on cops OR other racers and use EMPs to pass someone, and if you are a cop, you use all of these to take down racers. I especially enjoyed the cop career more because it is really fun to smash into other cars and send them into a barrel roll or other cool crashes.   NEUTRAL:   The free roam is one thing I always want in a racing game. Yes, Hot Pursuit does have it, but I feel that it is missing content. Being able to free roam as a racer, you would expect to occasionally run into a police car and get into some sort of epic chase, or vice versa being a cop, but sadly that just isn't the case. There aren't even any collectables! I guess the free roam in Hot Pursuit is pretty much there to test out cars or just go for a nice ride. So yes, it's nice to have, but it lacks content.  The menus are sub-par. You can very easily tell that it is more suited for consoles. While I strongly recommend using a controller for this game anyways, the least they could have done was provide a more intuitive menu for us PC gamers.   CONS:   With the exception of changing the color of the car, there is NO customization. I guess I 'spoiled' myself with the feature of customizing back when I played on the PS2 because now every NFS game that has come out recently has zero options to customize, and it has been very disappointing. I don't know why they ever took it out.  Now that I think about it, the menu tutorial at the very beginning of the game is really dumb and  unskippable . It's like they expect you to know absolutely nothing about how a menu works. It is completely useless and takes a couple minutes. Can't you just let us play the game already?    TL;DR:   NFS: Hot Pursuit is a really fun game with very nice graphics, great selection of cars, and tense racing. While free roam could have been significantly improved, it is always great to be able to go for a joyride in any of the vehicles you have unlocked, including the cop cars. Taking down racers or the police using EMPs, spike strips, roadblocks and more is very satisfying and really adds to the gameplay. There is no customization, with the exception of painting your car different colors, so this is a big let down, but nonetheless a very fun game. As a racing game enthusiast, I have to give this game a 7/10. Very fun!

There is no NFS game that came after this that is better. This game looks incredible yet runs well on many PCs. In fact, it looks better than many games released since 2010, even games released in 2015 and '16. Here is a list of Pros and Cons, as I do in most of my reviews.  Pros -Amazing graphics 6 years later, compared to other non-NFS games -Tons of cars to choose from (ranging from Mazda RX-8 and Subaru Impreza WRX STi to Bugatti Veyron) -You can play as a cop and a racer, which other NFS titles were lacking -Large open world (probably around 20x20 miles) -Lots of ambient sounds and awesome engine sounds -Special equipment for Racers and Cops (i.e. spike strips that can be deployed behind your car at high speeds, EMP to damage cars without ramming, etc) -Free Roam, which is great as you can just cruise in your favorite cars around a beautiful map Cons -The cars don't quite handle as well as they should, so you have to drift sometimes by briefly touching the brake then go around the corner in a quite-easy-to-control drift -You are forced to stay on the road and can't go offroad like in The Crew -Damage modeling is mediocre, a totaled car = ONLY a cracked windshield, bumper hanging by one end, and some dents and scratches -You can't get chased by cops in Free Roam -After a certain point you can't get any more 'levels' or 'points', unlike in the 2005 version of NFSMW where you could get wanted by the police to the point where they chased you in Corvettes the second they spotted you, regardless of what you were doing.

People who grew up playing NFS Underground 1 and 2 will most likely be disappointed, since the focus on customization and 4-cylinder tuners that they know and love aren't featured in this game.   People who know that Need For Speed existed before Underground will know that despite the powerups and pop music, this is the closest NFS has been to the original games in a long time.    Gameplay-wise, from an outside perspective, Hot Pursuit does what an arcade racer should do best and focuses on high-speed driving above all else. Not only is the game arcade-y from a physics perspective, but it's actually set up kind of like a game you'd see in an actual arcade; you don't buy or upgrade cars at all, nor do you unlock the city part by part. You simply have a list of available cars, you pick what you want, and you start racing. I can see how most people would think that might be a negative thing (I myself probably would have preferred buying and upgrading vehicles) but I think the 'quick race' approach works surprisingly well here. The driving feels good to me; the cars have a good amount of weight to them but are still easy to handle. Being able to play as a racer or a cop feels good too, and Criterion did a good job of infusing the game with some Burnout-influenced mechanics (such as takedowns and earning nitro) while still making Hot Pursuit feel distinctly like it's own game.  The game does have some faults though. There's not a lot of content, there's no way to set up custom races, and the only way to escape police is to take them down; you're not going to outrun them because they're some serious rubberbanding ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. Also, there's other ways in which the AI doesn't play by the same rules; if a computer-controlled racer's health bar hits zero and they total their car, they'll respawn with a brand new one. If you total yours, the race ends. Being able to crash your way out of a race is totally fine (I like it) but it's always frustrating in any game when the AI doesn't follow the same rules you do. It feels cheap. On top of all of this, the PC port is pretty sad. It'll run at 60fps and 1080p, but the graphical options you can choose are very limited. There's not even any options for things as simple as anti-aliasing.  All things considered, Hot Pursuit is a decent arcade racer with solid driving and mostly satisfying cop chases. The lack of content and barebones nature of the PC port are it's downfalls. If you want a fresh arcade racer, give this game a try...but only when it goes on sale.

Picked this up for 5 euro's which is about as much i would pay for this game.  Goal: So, the goal of the game seems to be to reach the highest ranking as either or both the racer and the cop, unlocking new cars in the progress. You will achieve both by doing races, including a variety of new cars which you then can race with. Well.. which you can sometimes race with I must say, because for some reason the game has its own preferences for cars and in some races you are just left with 1 pick (while the game shows you more unlocked cars, which you can't pick for some reason).   Then, there is no customization (sigh). A really big letdown for me, since this was what made the game series unique and was the biggest part of the reward system. This was what kept you playing, unlocking a new car, using your money to put some spoilers, wheels, neon lights etc. on it to make it your personal driving monster. Not being able to do this also made it less rewarding to unlock new cars like the camaro, which is one of my favorite cars.  So what about the leveling system, or the ranking system if you will.. well.. you unlock new cars and some new abilities (which you can only use for specific races), but thats pretty much it.. I felt no difference being a level 1 or a level 4 other than maybe difficulty.. Its just not rewarding enough anymore, since we all expect more.. If this game wasn't part of the nfs series, it would've been so much better.  Graphics: The graphics look average at best. I guess there went more time in actually letting players drive cars then the actual looks, which saddens me if i look back into the series. Most of the nfs games had pretty damn good graphics for their time, especially for a racing game. This wouldn't have bothered me as much if it were only the landscape, it is also the car models. I've seen way better looking car models in the older nfs's and I don't expect a game series like nfs's size to go worse in graphics.  Ok.. so far for the bad stuff.. lets recap a sec: there is (in my opinion) no real goal in the game other than winning races and gaining rank. The rewards are race specific abilities and cars, which are less rewarding since you can't even customize them. The graphics are average at best, the cars being the biggest let down for me (graphics wise).  The driving: So what is GOOD about the game, why should you buy it if you dissagree with the above? well.. the racing is pretty good, I love the drifting and the way nitro works in this game. It adds alot of tactic/strategy to the racing, which is cool. You can cut alot of turns or you can try and always get nitro back by driving against traffic, closely passing by cars and drifting (against traffic). Drifiting also is really important. You shouldn't always drift, and when drifting you get the choice of the optimal route or the route where you get the most nitro of.   Conclusion: So its up to you. my advice: if you look for a nfs game, just stay with carbon, it had really nice driving, police chases were epic (throwing wood of trucs to cut them off etc.), customization was still in the game and the game had somewhat of a story/sense of progression. If you are just looking for a racing game, don't really care about customization or graphics, but just (unrealistic) racing. Then this is your game. And ofcourse.. if you have 5 bucks spare.. you can look yourself and see if you share my opinion ^^!

This is the first Need For Speed game I've played in years. I might've played one of the older ones on the PS2, and I know I played the original The Need For Speed (yes, 'the' was part of the title at the time) back in 1994 on the 3DO. My point isn't to say, 'look at what an old gamer I am,' but instead to illustrate that I have relatively no way to compare this title againt contemporary NFS games.   GRAPHICS: The visuals are fantastic! The cars shine and reflect light and other objects, the roads kick up dirt and dust, and there's a day/night cycle.   There seems to be a distinct lack of anti-aliasing if you look closely, but given that you'll usually be going 300 KPH (that's 186 MPH) or so, you don't really have time to closely examine this. I imagine they decided to skip AA in favor of having higher framerates, which is more important in a high-speed racing game. Regardless, if you really need AA, you can always enable it through the Nvidia or ATI control panels.   CAMERA: There is no cockpit mode, so you won't get to simulate actually being in the car or looking around at the inside of the cabin. The closest thing to this is a camera view that seems like you're looking from on top of the car's hood. You can also drive without any object on the screen except the speedometer, in addition to the standard 'behind-the-car' view.  Personally, I kind of miss the cockpit view. It's not a dealbreaker by any means, but it would've been nice to have.  AUDIO: The game has plenty of engine rumbles and tires squealing. Really, the sound effects aren't anything noteworthy, but they're not bad either.   The music annoys me, however. This NFS title has an in-game radio that you can't shut off without muting all music. Your only other options are to choose between 'sequential' and 'shuffle' modes for the music. Maybe this isn't an issue if you like the music in the game (I think all the songs are from real bands, but I don't know for sure; my musical tastes are still stuck in the 1980s), but if you don't, prepare to mute it all. It would've been nice if we could add our own MP3 tracks, and there might be a way to do that, but I wouldn't know how.  HANDLING: This is a big one and probably the most subjective category. I think the cars handle great, but this is by no means a simulation. You're limited to accelerate, brake/reverse (hold the brake button down and the car shifts into reverse), the emergency brake, and oddly enough, the ignition, so you can actually turn your car on and off.   You can also turn your headlights on or off, and if they're off when night rolls around, they switch on automatically. You can still turn them off then and drive around in the dark, but it doesn't really have an effect on the gameworld (i.e. drivers don't honk or flash their headlights at you).  There's no way to change from an automatic transmission to a manual one in the game, despite most of the cars present probably have the latter or at least an option between the two. This doesn't really bother me as I always found a manual transmission to be distracting, but I know some people want it.   DAMAGE: Your cars can and do take damage, although it's practically all cosmetic. You'll get plenty of nicks, scratches, and even dents, but nothing will break nor will any damage affect your car's ability to function. The one and only time damage actually matters is if you hit an object at a fast enough speed with enough force to cause a fatal crash. Then the game shows a little sequence and then you restart back on the road.   CARS: What about the cars themselves? They're all real vehicles, fully licensed by the companies that make them. This is probably why damage is so limited.   It's neat to see the real car brands, as opposed to thinly-veiled knockoffs, but other than some information when choosing the car itself or knowing you're driving such-and-such vehicle, it does little to enhance the game.   MODIFICATION: This is strictly limited to paint color, and even that varies. Some cars don't even let you change the paint. You can't even change spoilers or headlights or tires, and you can forget about fine-tuning the engine.   Again, this is more of an arcade game, not a simulation, so perhaps expecting that level of detail is a bit much. I know I didn't, but I've read some complaints about it before.  STORY/CUTSCENES: There is no story. You simply play a speeder or a police officer, and have to complete missions and goals. When you do this successfully, you gain points (your 'wanted level') which can be used to unlock new cars.   The cutscenes are extremely annoying in that you can't skip them. This is particularly aggravating the first time you boot up the game, and each time you access a new area in the game itself. There are also a bunch of voiceovers, many of which occur when you select your vehicle. I think the automakers wanted a sales pitch to gamers and used this game as a way to do it.  ACCOUNT: Yes, there's a required account. No, you don't need Origin, but it does want your EA/Origin email and password. Without that, you can't sign into the game's account service (called 'Autolog') and thus can't play the game. VERDICT: I really like this game. It's not realistic, but it was never inteded to be either. If you want an arcade-like racing game that doesn't even pretend to have a storyline, and you don't mind using Autolog, I'd strongly recommend this game. To be short: did not live up to expectations.  To elaborate on that, I grew up with Need For Speed, specifically Need For Speed: Hot Pursuit 2. This may seem weird to some people, afterall how could the second in a series have come before the first; the reason for this is that this specific game is not the first Need For Speed: Hot Pursuit, rather it is a remake of the original Hot Pursuit duo. On the good side, this game made me very nostalgic; the map is very much like the map found in the old Hot Pursuit 2, the car selection is very similar to the old game, it doesn't have any customization or performance mods on the cars bogging down the experiance other than a selection of paint colors, and I could once again become the cop in a seperate cop campaign. In these ways it is very much like the game I learned to enjoy as a child.  However, on the darker side of things, these are the only apparant ways the two are similar. The game has done away with things that made the older game better to me; things like a behind the wheel camera view, quick race mode, and a decent tournament style ladder have been abandoned completely in favor of a gimicky multiplayer focused menu, wannabe social networking clone, and a pointless leveling system. As if that weren't bad enough, I could deal with those things, but the final nail in the coffin is transmission selection. Why? Because it doesn't exist. Every car is locked to automatic, probably to even the playing field in the earlier mentioned multiplayer focus. In the old game I would play manual every time because I found out early that you could shift a lot more effectively for yourself than the computer would for you, and I am sure any avid racing gamer would back me up on that. So imagine my surprise when I found out that the thing that let me be a better racer didn't even make it into the game.  What I am saying here is not meant to dissuade the casual gamer, this is a good game to sit down and go head to head with friends on. However anyone looking for a serious racing game should not get this game, the features are too light. In the same vein, if you found this game looking for a revitalized version of an old game you enjoyed you should look elsewhere, because it isn't here.

In this version, traffic interaction is almost non-existent and as a racer, you end up depending more on gizmos for breaking pursuits than skill or use of the environment (as in Most Wanted). Likewise when playing the cop, a well-timed PIT or skillful bumping of the racer into a roadblock would end the pursuit. In this version, not so much. If you try to pin a racer into a guardrail or other obstacle, they just blow through you as if you weren't even there... on the other hand repeated light taps from the rear damage the racer predictably (but unrealistically). So there's no reward for riskier maneuvers... just keep tapping their rear bumper until they eventually crash.  In the near 2 hours I've played so far, the races all have had the same overall feel. I've already laid out my complaints for the police mode. As a racer I haven't encountered any real ditch or out-run the police game modes which were so much fun in the originals. The modes are simply one race or time-trial after another.  In closing, I can't really decide whether to give this a recommended or not. My gut says no, because it just isn't as exciting as I remember many of the Pre-'05 versions being. Reading the various critic reviews, I have to wonder if any of the critics have been around long enough to have even played the originals, or if they simply came of age during the more recent releases and don't really have any perspective as to how much this release -lacks- anything innovating. Yes, the crashes are spectacular, but the gameplay required to induce them is simply uninspiring. I think given the $20 max price tag, I can recommend it... but it certainly has done nothing to restore my faith in the series.

need for speed hot pursuit is a game I highly recommend for anyone who is a fan of racing games and a game that I still recommend for those that are not.  just I thing to keep in mind when it comes to this review, it is entirely based off my single player experience as I have not touched the multiplayer part one bit.  and now on to what the game has going for it. well first off you have two choices on what to be, a reckless speed loving racer who will stop at nothing to finish the races, or a reckless speed loving cop who will stop at nothing to stop the racers cars dead flat and send them to jail.  the racers and cops do have a difference when playing as them as well. one of the biggest is that the racers nitros must be increased by doing reckless things such as drifting driving on the wrong side of the road and near misses.  the cop cars how ever have a slow but constant regenerating nitros. this helps you act a tiny little bit more like you should as it is sometimes better to drive in the right side of the road as a cop. (that's right as in right and wrong, not right and left)  the game also gives you lots of cool toys to mess with your opposition as you race. you got EMP's spike strips for both racers and the cops (the sneaky racers must have got them off the black market or something) with the cops getting road blocks and helicopters.  road blocks really help with the feeling that your not alone when trying to stop racers, just one button press and BAM there are 6 or so of you cop pals blocking the road for you.  the racers jammer how ever lets you stop EMP locks on you and turn off spike strips by making them fold back up.   the helicopter however I haven't unlocked but if I do ill add what it does here in the review.  now on to what type of races and stuff you can do as cops and racers.  so far ive only seen two types, a time trial of sorts and a average race either with or without cops for the racers and a timed chase to try and bust one or more racers.  but the variety of both the chases and the races more then makes up for this as not only will the racers and cops get harder on different tracks as it goes on but they give you access to more and better equipment as you get to later parts of the game.   and how is the A.I in this game? well I love it! at one point while racing I saw all 3 rival racers crash into one massive pile up. I know that might not be such a big deal but I just love games where they can and will screw up.  the difficulty is almost perfect in my opinion, starting you off with a bunch of easy missions to start you off and then unlocking more gear as you go as well as becoming harder.   the sound quality is excellent as well with a great choice of songs as well as proper and different sounding car noises and skidding noises.  this all sounds fine if you don't have a speaker that can't produce a lot of base, I found this out by first playing it on my now broken laptop and then moving to a tower computer with a base producing speaker.  the song choice is pretty good as well with 1 or 2 song choices that really fit going really fast. although I did get sick of it after a while as there is not as much choice as lets say most wanted, another need for speed game.  that is why I recommend looking up and if you can getting SSX3 and need for speed shift's soundtracks as they fit in perfectly in my opinion.  the graphics are pretty good as well with most of the cars looking very reall and just about nothing looking bad at the highest settings.  even a planes propellers looked good while I was sitting right next to it.  and on the highest or medium settings the game world looks so good, complete with rain snow and a day and night cycle.  there is also a free drive option in the game. this lets you be either a cop or a racer and just drive for the sake of it while taking in some views. its also good practice for honing your driving skills for when you do want to race.  or you can just mess around and try stuff like I did like obeying the laws and driving at the speed limit.   before I end this review I do have some warnings for certain things and stuff I don't like in the game.  I don't have just praise to give it.  #1 this game has very strict borders, its more like a race track then being fully open world and may create frustration or longing for a proper open world by some players when there’s nothing but a crappy little fence in your way.  #2 depending on how good your PC is your driving may seam very unresponsive to excellent, and there is no way to adjust the sensitivity when it comes to steering.  and that is with a 360 pad, the keyboard offers left or right with 1 set force of it  #3 this game is made by EA, so if you utterly hate them and don't want to support them in any way don't get it.  #4 each time you play the game you will be asked to create an EA account. this may frustrate some people so much that it ruins the game for them.  and #5 the game uses a medal system giving a bronze silver or gold depending on how well you do. im not certain about this but I think that you do need some gold or silver medals to get past some parts of the game, this means you could be stuck at a certain part for a long while.   and that's the end of my review. the game scores a 10/10 for me. its not perfect but I like it that much.

Years ago, I had a copy of Need for Speed: Hot Pursuit 2 on the PC. It was exciting races in fancy, expensive cars, accompanied by absurd street layouts that made for great tracks and wonderfully over-the-top police chases with pricey cop cars smashing head-first into racers with reckless abandon, raining explosive barrels down from the sky with the help of a helicopter, and generally creating absolute havoc in a way that was best compared to taking a bunch of toy cars and smashing them together, replete with sending them flying across the floor.  But my favorite part of that was something absent from most other titles of that ilk, Be the Cop Mode, which allowed you to take control of a pursuit vehicle and command the police forces at your will to arrest speeding drivers. And by 'arrest', I mean 'completely destroy the vehicle of'. It was ludicrous, and it was wonderful. When I heard about this, and that it was the developers of Burnout taking it on, I had high hopes.  They were met. And they were exceeded.  Being split into a Racer and Cop career means you get a lot of experience on both sides of the law, earning experience in the form of Bounty which rewards great runs but also makes sure you're always making some degree of progress. The cars start at luxury vehicles and work their way up to supercars and hypercars, and the police pursuit vehicles are... well, for the most part, variants of the Racer vehicles with lightbars and a livery slapped on. It's as satisfying as ever to teach a bunch of Pagani joyriders multi-million dollar lessons in the speed limit by smashing them off the sides of cliffs in a Veyron, and as thrilling a power fantasy as ever to destroy half a county's police force in a bulky GT-R.  The game is set in one great, big, interconnected map, but this is more like Underground 1 than 2 and onwards; the open-world element of the game is reserved for specific pursuit missions and a completely separate mode that lets you drive around for fun with no progress made. (Irritatingly, it's here where it becomes obvious that the police sirens and lightbars cannot actually be shut off.) Mostly this just means you'll get to recognize certain bends of road across various events, which are still linear point-to-point races for the most part.  A fantastic licensed soundtrack is accompanied with a wonderful (if more generic) orchestral pursuit soundtrack in the vein of NFS:MW'05, although bizarrely, the same six or so pursuit songs are re-used for every single event involving a police pursuit. Which as the game's name implies, is most of them. So the licensed soundtrack is great in the very few instances you actually get to hear it.  The physics are a skillful mix of arcadey elements with, well, actual racing strategy. If you know what you're doing and try to apply real-world racing lines to it, it'll mostly work. Just expect to drift a lot more than is reasonable. You charge nitrous with stunts, meaning Racers will want to maximize time in the oncoming lane and Cops will want to cut close with traffic. Netting a Takedown will fully recharge, so you'll have plenty of reason to go full aggro if that's what does it for you. And like KERS, and as ever with NFS, nitrous is best applied coming out of corners and finding a good rhythm for it.  The items and weapons aren't exclusive to the police like they were in games past; Racers and Cops now have their own suites of weapons. Both have access to spike strips (mercifully temporary in effect now, spinning out drivers instead of handicapping them for the entire event) and EMPs (yes, as in electromagnetic pulses, I'm not making that up). Police can call in roadblocks (with care, because if you do it right near an obvious path around a roadblock, they absolutely will be in the most useless spot possible) and helicopters (which no longer hurl exploding barrels into traffic, but now just drop spike strips with extreme skill). Racers can use a jammer to prevent police from calling in any of their weaponry, and can also use a horrifically powerful Turbo boost that... well, find a good straight for it and hold on for dear life, because the effect is striking.  The comedic tone is a massive plus for me. It's nothing extremely distracting, but it's definitely more light-hearted than many titles out there. Police chatter has officers reporting making their fiftieth ticket today, calling in EMS only to be told the tow truck is on its way, and calling their attacks by radioing them in to Central. It feels like playing with toy cars; it's purely the fantasy of speed with none of the ridiculous grimdark garbage that's pumped into a lot of street racing titles to create drama.  In short, this is a fantastic game that works well with novelty, but by no means coasts on it. It makes glorious, ridiculous street races with high-tech supercars slamming into each other, police calling in EMP blasts to send racers soaring off the road, and generally just hooning cars around corners exactly as fun as it should be. One of the best Need for Speed titles I've played, and one of the best racers overall.

In Need For Speed Hot Pursuit, you either play as a racer trying to evade the law, or as a cop trying to stop racers. A relatively simple idea, but the basis for a fantastic game. You can use weapons against your opponents, like EMP blasts or spike strips, and that's the main area that this game differentiates itself from others. The weapons make for a great game of cat and mouse, and mixed with the feeling of speed and the noticabally last gen but silky smooth graphics, you're sure to have a good time.  The game puts a lot of emphasis on Autolog, a system where you can compare your times on every event to the time's of your friends. It's a great idea in theory... But that game doesn't link to your Steam friends list! Oh okay, so maybe it links to Origin? Nope, this game predates Origin! So basically, you're stuck without any friends when you start, and the 'autolog reccomendations' section remains annoyingly empty...  Luckily there is a solution, just jump online and play some of the multiplayer, and you'll be able to add people from the room you're in. Then, their friends will start being reccomended to you, and you can add them to your friends list. Just keep adding friends this way and eventually you'll have a lot of autolog competition! Also, you can import your favourites into Origin if you want to.  The multiplayer is even more fun than the single player. The only people who are playing now seem to be very good at the game, which makes sense for a game this old, but still, it's brilliant. The cat and mouse excitement of the single player is ramped up to the maximum level when you know it's real people you'll be running off the road. It's a testament to how fun the multiplayer is that people still play it. It's a shame that it's so hard to link up to your friends, it's very hard to find the option to enter a friend's username.  So all in all, Need For Speed Hot Pursuit is a great game which is somewhat hampered by it's implementation on PC. No links to friends lists, no achievements... But it makes up for it with it's awesome gameplay. Oh and the soundtrack's pretty good too, did I mention that?  Add me by the way, i'm CyberAly.
